title: Cauchy's integral theorem
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, the Cauchy integral theorem (also known as the Cauchy–Goursat theorem) in <a href="complex%20analysis">complex analysis</a>, named after <a href="Augustin-Louis%20Cauchy">Augustin-Louis Cauchy</a> (and <a href="%C3%89douard%20Goursat">Édouard Goursat</a>), is an important statement about <a href="line%20integral">line integral</a>s for <a href="holomorphic%20function">holomorphic function</a>s in the <a href="complex%20number">complex plane</a>. Essentially, it says that if formula_1 is analytic in a simply connected domain Ω, then for any simply closed contour formula_2 in Ω, that contour integral is zero.

(Recall that a curve is <a href="Homotopy">homotopic</a> to a constant curve if there exists a smooth <a href="homotopy">homotopy</a> from the curve to the constant curve. Intuitively, this means that one can shrink the curve into a point without exiting the space.) The first version is a special case of this because on a <a href="Simply%20connected%20space">simply connected</a> set, every closed curve is <a href="Homotopy">homotopic</a> to a constant curve.

Discussion.
As <a href="%C3%89douard%20Goursat">Édouard Goursat</a> showed, Cauchy's integral theorem can be proven assuming only that the complex derivative formula_29 exists everywhere in formula_13. Political significance.
The German mathematician <a href="Ludwig%20Bieberbach">Ludwig Bieberbach</a> disparaged this theorem, claiming it was representative of an abstract style of reasoning that was characteristic of Jews and speakers of Romance languages, but foreign to Germans. Bieberbach founded the Nazi-linked <a href="Deutsche%20Mathematik">Deutsche Mathematik</a> movement that sought to purge German mathematics of these influences. In a series of lectures he opined that “The Cauchy-Goursat theorem arouses intolerable displeasure in us Germans. But certainly not in a <a href="Edmund%20Landau">Landau</a>. Such a thing is mentally determined. … All in all, such juggling with concepts and a pronounced shrewdness characterize the nonorganic, hostile S type, especially Jewish mathematics.”
